body:
This is a bit different from say [`tf.zeros`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/zeros) in Python, where the shape can be a tensor (i.e., something that isn't fully known at graph construction time).

For example:

```python
import tensorflow as tf

shape = tf.random_uniform([2], minval=1, maxval=5, dtype=tf.int32)
zeros = tf.zeros(shape)

with tf.Session() as sess:
  for _ in range(5): print sess.run(zeros.shape)
```

You'll see different shapes of the zeros on each call to `sess.run` - it isn't a graph construction time constant.
Wouldn't we want the same for the Java zeros?
body_html:
This is a bit different from say tf.zeros in Python, where the shape can be a tensor (i.e., something that isn't fully known at graph construction time).

For example:

import tensorflow as tf

shape = tf.random_uniform([2], minval=1, maxval=5, dtype=tf.int32)
zeros = tf.zeros(shape)

with tf.Session() as sess:
  for _ in range(5): print sess.run(zeros.shape)

You'll see different shapes of the zeros on each call to sess.run - it isn't a graph construction time constant.
Wouldn't we want the same for the Java zeros?
body_text:
This is a bit different from say tf.zeros in Python, where the shape can be a tensor (i.e., something that isn't fully known at graph construction time).
For example:
import tensorflow as tf

shape = tf.random_uniform([2], minval=1, maxval=5, dtype=tf.int32)
zeros = tf.zeros(shape)

with tf.Session() as sess:
  for _ in range(5): print sess.run(zeros.shape)
You'll see different shapes of the zeros on each call to sess.run - it isn't a graph construction time constant.
Wouldn't we want the same for the Java zeros?
